title: E3D Titan Universal Duel Fan Mount

description.text:
I needed a better flowing fan for my E3d Titan Set up. I could not find one like this so i spliced two designs together and added a little geometry for support. I have built one and tweaked it, this is good working print. Huge improvement in flow and cooling over my last set up. Prints already looking better. Should be universal and just mount to right to the fins with a snug fit no needs for mounts.

I have Edited it 5 times now to where I really like it. Notched, extended, enforced, now with loops for a small zip if you so wish. Works awesome with my setup right now printing on regular old pla, using a heat bed at high temps no warp age and its right up on the part. Fully universal and height adjustable this is a great blower set up.

I've always hated it when there is no room for an end table, or heck, when there just isn't a place to set your drink. So after designing my Mountable Gear Shaped Cup Holders http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235067 for my arcade cabinet I decided that a double swing arm design would be handy for next to the bed, next to the computer, on the wall next to the bath tub... or wherever! I stuck with the gear shape, cause I love gears (I used my business logo for the shape). The images are currently of a draft mode print of the prototype, I am printing a much more solid / functional / updated version right now, I'll update the pics as soon as it's done.
UPDATE:
Added the new pic, I stopped the print before it put the top layers on the gear because I was digging the look of the infill. They are surprisingly solid at the higher resolution print settings with a more solid infill. I ended up going with bolts, the 3d printed pins were extremely easy to break. I spray painted the finished parts with hammerite for a sort of metallic look. Also, I found that with the right bolts and nuts, it can hold a 22oz beer (with the parts printed at maximum length).

I've designed some Pins for the mount holes, you are probably better off using actual bolts with nuts for the connections, but if your like me and are too lazy to go to the store for bolts, there are the pins for now. If you print the connection pins at a high resolution with a fairly solid infill they should, hopefully, maybe, might possibly, work?
EDIT: Nope, the 3d printed pins absolutely did not work. I went to the hardware store and just found some bolts long enough along with some washers and lock nuts. The bolts were 1/4-20 x 2-1/2...

I added 150mm arms in addition to the 219mm arms, so how long you want it to be is up to you and your print bed size.

As always, I hope you guys like it and maybe someone else will find it useful. Please post pics of your makes, I love seeing if others actually decided to make something I designed ;)

"cause if they don't find you handsome, they should at least find you handy!" -Red

This is addition of the Geometric Flower of life pot I made. This file is scaled up to 700% over the small original file. I have it set at this scale as its the size of pot I plan to print.
This is a unique design, as I was thinking of figet spinners i was spinning the small sized flower pot on my finger, I got the idea to have a spinning flower pot.
So I cut up a figet spinner, and put it at the bottom of the pot, then put a finger cover for a bearing in the middle of the water tray, and added some new water holes.

Thinking about this design more. I may cap off the inside where the bearing will sit as to not get water and dirt in it. Either way will be a very long print. Combined around 20 hours for my printer, this will be sold on esty and local selling apps if it turns out good. Will be updating this week.

remixed_from.author: svhb
remixed_from.title: Anet A8 Dovetail Accessory and Spoolholder Mount

title: Parametric Spoolholder for Anet A8 type printers

description.text:
Very preliminary parametric version of my Dovetail Spool Mount for Anet A8 and similar printers.

Generate test pieces by setting Piece to 4 and 5. Use these to adjust "looseness" parameter.

Looseness of 0 will probably be impossible to assemble, but this of course depends on your individual printer. Mine is not calibrated very well, so I use a looseness of around 0.2. I think a well adjusted printer might work with about 0.1. Print the two test pieces with varying looseness until you get a satisfactory fit.

Once you have a looseness selected, print Pieces 1, 2 and 3 (don't forget to set the looseness each time).

You can also choose to add "anti-warp grooves", which are meant to reduce the possibility of warping due to poor bed adhesion.

And of course you can adjust the height to support larger or smaller spools. Currently heights higher than 150mm aren't really supported, the lightening holes won't be positioned very well.

The last parameter ($fn) adjusts the number of segments used to generate circles, arcs, cylinders, etc. I like 72 personally, but you can adjust it higher if you want "extra round" circles, or lower if you want more segmented circles. You can even set it to 6 to get hexagonal holes.

print_settings.Resolution:: Works OK at Medium resolution. I printed mine at .32
print_settings.Notes:: Warning
print_settings.Infill:: 20% is fine.  Avoid cubic infill - it doesn't do well on thin walls.

description.text:
3D printers are very attractive to young and old - core x/y printers, like the D-Bot even more-so. One of those very attractive parts is the open-motor-pulley-belt on each of the front top corners. Dangly bits (both young and old) can easily get grabbed by one of these dangly bits grabbers. Of course, there's not enough force to really hurt most bits, but it will mess up your print should it happen.

In addition, in a D-bot build (and most core x/y printers) 4 of the 5 stepper motors have the shafts pointing up and lots of cruft can build up.in that area.

To keep all sorts of bits off the working ends of the x/y motors, I made this set of motor covers.

They were specifically designed for the printed corner motor mounts of spauda01's very popular D-Bot build: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1001065 which I, too, am in the process of building. The dimensions and the top profile of my motor covers matches those mounts and there are two little clips that fit into specific spots on those brackets. But even if these won't work for your specific printer, perhaps they'll make you want to sit down and design your own.

In use, these slide over the bracket from the front and two clips on the cover will clip it into place on the bottom of the bracket near the corners of the stepper motor. The first time you put it in place, hold it firmly against the motor mount and squeeze the sides gently so the clips will seat and know where to clip on.

You may notice that, as in most core x/y printers, the two x/y motors are at different heights and my motor covers are not. I debated making one tall enough to be flush to the top of the taller motor mount, but it looked a little silly - like a clock tower or something, so i decided against it.

OK. Now just because I wanted to cover up and protect the motors, that doesn't mean I want to crush the spirits of the bystanders, young and old. And besides, the end of the stepper motor shaft is just a few millimeters and one hole away. So I have a second version of the covers that has a small hole positioned directly above the motor shaft. I've included a small platform with a shaft that friction-fits the 5mm D-shaft of the stepper motor. A little bit of hot glue will attach lots of interesting things that can twirl back and forth while you're printing. Beware: the motors can spin very quickly and can reverse direction almost instantly. Use very low mass, low cross-section items - not so much for your own safety, since I know you are all reasonable folk, but you can easily mess up a print if you get too enthusiastic.

I've included pictures of examples - paper cutouts hot-glued to the included platform. I also included a picture of something that makes me laugh out loud every time I imagine one hot-glued to the each of the included platforms. Every time.

The hole will also accommodate most modest-diameter stepper motor knobs, including my own: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2217980 . I'm not sure, yet, of the practicality of having those hanging on the left-right x/y motors, but they look nice when they spin.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Works OK at Medium resolution. I printed mine at .32

Infill:

20% is fine. Avoid cubic infill - it doesn't do well on thin walls.

Notes:

Print upside down. The 45degree slope should be easily handled by any printer. I printed 2 perimeters during development and 3 for my final versions. I oriented the parts as shown in the stl files and had my slicer put the seam on the "back" side since that will be the unseen inside when in use.

PLA is fine - there's no need for heat resistance or high strength for this part. The red and dark blue caps in my pictures are PETG - the same as my D-bot's printed parts - the others are PLA.

Warning: The stepper motor shafts will spin very quickly when you're printing. If you attach anything to the included shaft toppers, make it very low mass and with a modest cross-section. And don't grab the attachment while it's spinning. You probably won't hurt yourself, but you'll certainly mess up your print.

remixed_from.author: crozone
remixed_from.title: Vive Welding Headgear Adapter for Jackson Safety 370

description.text:
A reversible clip you can use to replace your HTC Vive headband with a quick release welding headband.

We have a lot of different people try the VR gear and the stock HTC headband was too hard to adjust. The Jackson 370 welding headband works so much easier.

I first tried Ryan Crosby's fix but the Jackson turn screws were in the way of my headphones. Modified his design in Rhino 5.0.

To use:
1 Print out 2 of these
2 Order the Jackson Safety 370 Replacement Headgear
3 Cut off the front (padded) part of the headgear with scissors.
4 Remove all the turnscrews and clips from the headgear.
5 Take off the HTC headband.
6 It's a bit of a struggle to get this clipped in but once you do it's good and solid. You need to clip the 3d printed clips into the middle hole on the Jackson headband.
7 Slide the Vive clips into the slots of 3d printed parts and then use a zip tie to pull it tight.

It is a round 2 test now - been working a while but will probably need another iteration.

A vital addition to my 3d printer. The normal method of adjusting the sensor was error prone. I decided to design my own:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/dcc1f9dde62812e487e0f4f0/w/8b5d634ec760dcef3be76e7b/e/49c37c0e2856f71f31345d80

Credit for the idea goes to parable, I based my design on his clever idea: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1534152

The main benefit is that it is compact and no sanding is required.

I believe that based on the M4 with a pitch of 0.7mm, 1mm of vertical movement would be 1/0.7=1.43 turns. So a 16th of a turn is 0.09mm.

Print both parts upside down, the "SN04-mount-and-slider-v6" stl and gcode are already done like this ready to print.

Spring, I had a 7mm x 19mm compression spring from a Rolson set 61298:
http://www.rolsontools.com/150pc-spring-assortment.html

One of:
M4 x 50mm hex bolt
M4 wing nut (or print a thumbscrew)

Two of:
M3 x 25mm button hex head
M3 nut
M3 x 6mm button hex head

I got the nuts/bolts from ebay:
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/251363699166
Size M4
Thread Pitch 0.7mm
Head Size Across Flats 7mm
Head Thickness 2.9mm
Material A2/70
Specification DIN933

I bought 10 because this camera tripod design also uses the M4 x 50mm:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1165406

Hictop Prusa i3 3DP-17

Fitting

Fitting is not too difficult, I did:

  1. Home printer
  2. Unscrew SN04 sensor
  3. Use LCD menu to move head up about 50mm
  4. Attach sensor to slider using the M3 x 25mm bolts and M3 nuts, the sensor should hang on the bolts
  5. Attach the mount to the Hictop mount using the M3 x 6mm
  6. Insert the M4 bolt up through the slider and the spring on top
  7. Add the wing nut and tighten
  8. Using the LCD menu again, lower the head back to 0mm
  9. Use the wing nut to place the sensor so that the LED just comes on

That should be it. Homing should return the head to the same place. I checked before and after using feeler gauges which were approx 0.25mm. When the head and bed is hot this gap is approx 0.1mm.

Now when you are printing if you know that the head is not right you can turn the wing nut slightly up or down to adjust fractionally.

title: OpenTactics Lava Tiles (18mm Scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This modular terrain is for our OpenTactics project. If you're familiar with Pocket-Tactics, it runs on a very similar system except that the maps are blown up to scale with the characters (as shown here). We'll be releasing a beta set soon, along with fully customizable rules options so you can make your own characters, monsters, vehicles, et cetera, and share them with the community (as well as use this system with any gaming miniatures). These tiles are sized to our 18mm scale character models, and will work well with any system that allows for grids (including Dungeons & Dragons and Pathfinder).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want!

Thanks for looking!

title: 92mm Fan to 100mm Pipe Adaptor for UK Pipe Flange

description.text:
Designed to sit over a 92mm PWM Fan with space to run cables and connect it to a 100mm PVC Pipe Flange, I made this part as a piece for my air recirculation system. I connected it to a 90 degree elbow to a rectangular 100mm PVC Pipe at each end to feed air round my enclosure from top left to bottom right to even out air temperature over the whole height.

This will totally enclose the fan and is intended to be silicone sealed both to the enclosure and to the PVC Pipe, although you can use it any way you wish :)

UPDATES:

Version 1: Sizing was incorrect, leading to pipes not fitting and the fan being too tight
Version 1.5: Resized to 105% and reprinted this made the junction between the pipe flange and the fan cover too slim so it broke very easily
Version 2: Resized the parts to better fit over the fan, ensured the pipe flange Internal Diameter is accurate. attempted to strengthen the junction - will update once reprinted!

description.text:
Batman Fidget with a bearing race embedded in the model. It will take up to 11 4.5mm BBs. I am using 10 BBs in my prints with a little bearing grease. I ended up driving a push pin through the center race to keep the two sides together on my first print. The second print works well with CA glue to hold the two center peices together. I am using 10 Pennies, 5 on each side with CA glue to help keep them in place. The center race halves are based on the
"Finger_Pad_V2_Twisted_Pins.STL" by 2ROBOTGUY. I set the pennies in a heads/tails configuration for my son to be able to play heads or tails with the fidget. This thing doesn't spin forever like a standard 608ZZ bearing does, but it is still fun. Word of caution, the edges are very pointy, may cause calluses on your fingers with prolonged use.

title: Mentos-Diet Coke Cannon Pin Lock & Adapter

description.text:
I printed Bluemetal's DC-M Cannon for use at the Perot Museum of Nature & Science and loved how it worked. Only problem is after a few uses, the pin tends to work itself out resulting in spray emitting from the hole! So I designed a pin lock to stop the pin from being fully extracted. Just print and super glue onto the pin after it is in place. I positioned it so the smooth (build plate) sides of each piece were towards each other to give a better glue surface.

I also made an adapter that will connect the cannon with 1/2" PVC pipe. They wanted a way to shoot off the cannon "in a more controlled environment"......no fun, but also way less messy! I've included the adapter as well. You may need to sand the pipe or adapter depending on the calibration of your printer. I usually just force fit the PVC and cannon together. It does leak a little bit..

The dimensions are made thick enough that you can get away with 20-30% fill.  However, if you have the time for a long print it might be worth upping the in-fill to 60-70% for a nice solid part.  If you are using this in a laser lab (as I probably will at some stage) it might be worth building with a finer layer resolution and more fill to reduce any possibility of pointing jitter.

description.text:
This is a laser pointer mount that I made for a school outreach project: a mini Michelson interferometer. It holds a standard pocket laser pointer with two 1/4"-20 screws and is fixed with a 8-32 screw on the bottom.

You will need two 1/4"-20 standard nuts that you gently melt into the hex shaped holes at the top with a soldering iron - this give a nice strong thread to hold hold the laser in place. Its a very tight fit, this is so that once melted into place you have a solid build with no glue. The mount can be fixed to standard laser lab 1/4" or 1" posts with a 8-32 socket head screw.

Printer:

CraftBot PLUS

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm

Infill:

30-60 %

Notes:

Print oriented vertically, that is, with the long edge pointing upwards.

Use brim platform adhesion for a guaranteed build.

You want a thicker shell (i.e. 0.8 to 1.2 mm), this is so there is enough material for the hex bolt holes to melt into. The dimensions are made thick enough that you can get away with 20-30% fill. However, if you have the time for a long print it might be worth upping the in-fill to 60-70% for a nice solid part. If you are using this in a laser lab (as I probably will at some stage) it might be worth building with a finer layer resolution and more fill to reduce any possibility of pointing jitter.

title: The Drakkar (18mm Scale Remix)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I took MakerBot's amazing Drakkar longship and rescaled it for 18mm tabletop gaming. Some of the features aren't perfectly to scale, but the heart of the ship is pretty dang close. We will be using it to test our new project, OpenTactics.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Discord, and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want!

Thanks to MakerBot for allowing everyone to use this great model!

Gotta love the NES. I had seen a few designs around here, but none of them color-printable. So after a few trial-redesign rounds, here is the final result :)

1) Print the body in white, A+B in red, and cross+start+select in blue/black.
2) Assemble all the buttons, you can use soft foam to make them "press-able".
3) 2D print the sticker (if you happen to have one of those rare 2D printer), plastify it, cut the holes with an X-Acto knife, and glue it in place.
4) You can also put a cable with a connector to make it even more realistic. Design made in Sketchup. Again, I'm sorry for that. Summer is near and I will learn OpenSCAD soon.

description.text:
A quirky "backwards" clock where the hour and minute dials are attached to the hand mechanisms and rotate to display the current time at the top of the clock.

I designed it for this mechanism from Amazon UK:
https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00SK58GTY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o00_s00

There are grooves in the holes in the dials to fit rubber o-ring's to grip to the mechanism - 1mm for the minute / 4.8mm for the hour.

The diameter of the base is 130mm, ~110mm for the hour dial, ~90mm for the minute, and ~10mm for the height of the numbers.

It's a bit smaller than I had anticipated and will look at scaling it up a bit at some point. It could probably also do with a cap for the middle of the dials.

https://youtu.be/C4Eenw_H1Jo

The base has a threaded hole to screw to the clock mechanism, so I used a 0.2mm layer height for that, but 0.3mm for everything else.

title: Baby Buffalo - Fixed Thumbstick for CH2 0.50 pulse width.

description.text:

Build the Baby Buffalo according to these instructions
https://www.electric-skateboard.builders/t/gt2b-baby-buffalo-mod-case-3d-printable-thumb-throttle-case/4694

but print this throttle stick instead.

When connecting the steering pot to channel 2, you will get a 40 or 60% default pulse width with the MK1 throttle stick. This causes problems with long disconnects when it reverts to 50%.

Enjoy!

author: Team_B

description.text:
A 3-D rendering of Boy's surface. The design starts in Sage, export to X3D (resulting file included), then import X3D into Blender. In Blender, edit to remove artifacts Sage leaves behind (like a cube of lines around the figure, which can also be removed in Sage using option "frame=False" as seen in Sage code below), then "thicken" the surface so that Cura can recognize it as a solid object:

  1. select Properties -> Modifiers (wrench icon) -> Add Modifier -> Solidify
  2. set Thickness to 0.1 and click Apply

Now export to STL, then import STL into Cura. In Cura, scale (because graph units in Sage become millimeters in Cura) and situate figure on print platform, then export STL again to form the STL thing file here.

Here is the Sage code to generate the figure:

p,t=var('p,t')
u=cos(t)*sin(p)
v=sin(t)*sin(p)
w=cos(p)
x=(1/2)*((3*u^2-1)+2*v*w*(v^2-w^2)+u*w*(u^2-w^2)+u*v*(v^2-u^2))
y=(sqrt(3)/2)*((v^2-w^2)+u*w*(w^2-u^2)+u*v*(v^2-u^2))
z=(u+v+w)*((u+v+w)^3-4*(u-v)*(v-w)*(w-u))
parametric_plot3d([x,y,z], (t,0,2*pi), (p,0,pi), frame=False)

Since Sage is Python-based, be sure to check line breaks.

The parameterization in the Sage code is based on the variables t and p representing spherical coordinate angles, giving u, v, and w as coordinates of points on the unit sphere in space, then x, y, and z on the actual surface. The surface is an immersion of the projective plane into 3-space. The immersion is self-intersecting but does not have any singularities ("pinch points").

This surface presents a minor issue for slicer software because of its topology. Even setting infill in the slicer, this figure remains hollow -- topologically, it doesn't have an "inside," similar to a Klein bottle. This is why it is necessary to "solidify" the surface in Blender, even though by all appearances the surface seems closed.

There is a statue of Boy's surface at the Mathematics Research Institute at Oberwolfach:
http://www.mfo.de/general/boy/boy_small.jpg
The statue was a gift to the Institute from the Mercedes-Benz corporation, designed on a computer and manufactured using equipment at Mercedes-Benz.

remixed_from.author: JimmyShawsTidbits
remixed_from.title: Geeetech Aluminum Prusa I3 Anti-Wobble Bracket

description.text:
Z wobble was horrible on my CTC i3 (you'll see it in the photos I've uploaded).

I saw Jimmy's video on YouTube (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zx8fhBA4JwY) and found the part but it needed to be level for my printer so redesigned it slightly to suit.

I printed a new benchy and did the comparison photo in the files and although there are still other artefacts and issues to solve, the Z wobble was much improved!

Simply place an M8 nut in each part, remove the x axis and then the lead screw nut from the printed parts. Place the new parts onto the threaded rod and then seat the X carriage, minus the removed lead screw nuts on top of the new printed parts. Make sure the X carriage is square to the bed and level and print!

Printer:

CTC Prusa i3 Pro B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%
Add an M8 nut to the bottom of each part, it will push in until flush with the bottom.

author: UEPONYA

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Y-axis assembly tool

description.text:
I had many problems with the Y-axis assembly on my prusa i3 mk2s.
The distance measurement between the rods with the frame isnt really acurate and the manual doesnt give you any information about the exact distance.
I found a video at the online manual with the correct distance.
But my callipers couldnt measure it (distance was too big).
So i designed this to make it perfect now.

Just print it (maybe twice) put it between the rods and you got the perfect distance.

comments.text: According to your tool dimension is 162 mm. On my printer I did not use any exact measure. I released nuts on one side and then slided bed carriage front and back so there is minimal drag resistance on bearings. Aligned front and rear rod distance on same dimension so it is parallel and that was it.
comments.author: drznedaj

comments.text:
Yes, the dimensions from inside to inside is 162mm.
At prusa tutorial they measure the outside with 178mm.

author: Paddes

title: Tronxy P802M (Prusa i3) Proximity Switch Holder With CREE LEDs

description.text:
I added a proximity probe to automatically level my Tronxy (Prusa i3 Clone) 3D Printer. I also wanted better lighting. This replacement allowed me to add both.

Some notes:
1) My printer has an aluminum heating surface. This is covered by a piece of borosilicate glass with a PEI sheet. Even this larger proximity probe can't detect the aluminum through the glass because it's a weak signal and it's too far away. I added a thin piece of copper between the glass and the aluminum, and it detects it with about a 1/16" gap between the probe and the glass. Something steel would likely work better, but I had the copper already.

2) When you set up the probe, be sure that the heating surface and the extruder are at temperature before you set zero. Elsewise, things move around enough to throw off the readings.

3) I kept the original Z switch. I set it slightly lower than the probe detection so that it trips if the probe does not work. This has saved me a couple of times already. Once was when I was building the electronics and testing the system, and a couple of times was when the extruder was not up to temperature, and a hard piece of filament stuck to the extruder or onto the build surface caused the print head assembly to twist and not set off the proximity probe.

4) The LEDs I used are CREE. They were given to me, so I don't know exactly where they came from. You can find them by searching for "cree chanzon" on eBay. The way the holder is designed, they fit into recesses, and the wire on the resistor locks them into place through 1/16" holes in the extrusion. I put a drop of solder on them to help the connection.

5) The resistor for the LEDs is a 2W. Electrically, a 1W is sufficient, but gets hotter. Plus, I already had a 2W.

6) I had a lot of trouble flashing the Melzi board with Marlin firmware. I finally got it to flash by removing the micro SD card. Look for user 10k on the RepRap Forums for more info.

7) This thing lacks flat surfaces to make for easy printing. I printed it standing up on the right edge (right as mounted on the printer), with supports.

8) I get a lot better adhesion on a more consistent basis with the Proximity Probe. I highly recommended this mod!

description.text:
I started printing Mjolnir from ChaosCoreTech. Great files by the way! His original files of the handle printed in 3 pieces. When I would print the handle, I would get a lot of stringing from the overhanging "ribs", because of no support. So I ended up cutting the handle up into pieces, so that when printing, each "rib" would print using the bed for support. I could not be happier with the result. In addition to that, I created square keys for easily re-aligning and gluing the handle together. I ended up totally rebuilding the single handle piece and smoothed out all surfaces.

I also rebuilt the bottom and top pieces of the handle for a smoother surface. All scroll work is the original work from ChaosCoreTech.

For the actual body of the hammer, I cut it into smaller sections, so I'm not held hostage by my printer for 12 hours at a time. For the end cap, with all the scroll work, I cut it into 5 pieces. Each scroll piece being it's own, plus the actual end cap. The scroll pieces print flat on the print bed for a clean print. No clean up afterwards. Just attach to the end cap with your favorite adhesive. The end cap has cylindrical keys for easy attachment to body part C. The rest of the body must be perfectly aligned and glued.

The head cap with scroll work is slightly tweaked from Remih. I made it slightly bigger and thicker. Enjoy.

Just added my lathe jig also! So you can turn the handle pieces on the lathe for a quick sanding!!!

Just added a new pommel. This one has a hole for a leather strap. I also omitted the rib on the pommel. I used a 2" heat shrink tubing for the handle wrap and that last rib was giving me issues. The shrink tubing has an adhesive lining, which helps re-inforce the strength of the handle, but that last rib was keeping the wrap from seating properly. I'll add the new pommel with that last rib later for those who want it.

Also just added an updated version of the scroll piece that goes with Body A. This scroll piece has a few extra "scroll" pieces added to fill the small voids that the original has.

print_settings.Notes:: Here is a link to it.

description.text:
EDIT: I would LOVE it if anyone who has printed it gave me feedback on how they think their prints change? I have seen no issues with mine prints getting any extra issues due to the whole printer moving slightly but would love to hear if you have. :) Thanks

I created this as I wasn't happy with the designs for the existing Anti-Vibration feet/legs that were on Thingiverse.
These hold up the 10mm threaded bars that run under the bed's smooth rods on the Original Prusa MK2/S and with the help of elastic bands cause the whole printer to float and transfer absolutely no noise into the table.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Use:

To use them print them up side down so the legs point up (no supports should be required as I designed them to never exceed 45% overhangs).

You will need at least 3 but I recommend 4.

Once printed get a small pack of elastic bands and:
1) Working from the centre feed the band though one of the holes and hook the end of the band around the outer poll
2) Feed the other end of the band though the hole on the opposite side and again around the poll. (IF your band isn't tight you might need to instead loop the band around the poll and feed it back though the two holes and hook it around the first poll again so you're doubling it's stretch)
3) Repeat this for the other side.
4) Test the weight of one corner by placing the 10mm threaded rod on top of the bands (so it cross the bands at 90deg). If it sits to low then add more (or stronger) bands.
5) Now repeat for the other 3 corners and relax as the vibration noise has gone! :D

NOTE: You will also likely need to add more/stronger bands to the back supports as most of the weight is there. ESPECIALLY if your spool is also on top of the printer!

This is the first working version and they do work great but there are some changes I MIGHT make as they aren't easy to thread the elastic bands though the tiny holes...

Fusion 360:

I created this in Fusion 360. Here is a link to it.

First test one worked fine so here are the other 3 required for full support. :) The fun an slightly slow process of adding the bands. The red bands in the back images are just temporarily placed there. They will go over the bar to hold the supports to the bar when you lift the printer up. One of the back ones in place. I did take this off and replace the bands with stronger ones as it was sitting a bit low due to the back weighing more but it works perfectly!

description.text:
I've been fortunate enough to grab a Nintendo switch! I've put about 20 hours into gaming and I noticed I was really dissatisfied the way the remote sat in my hand. Because of the led's lighting up on the control holder (it's actually a neat optic trick.) , I didn't want to replace that. THOUGH, I really wanted better grips. So I grabbed a collection of old remotes, held them, and asked myself, "Why does this feel better?". This is the end result. More design improvements coming!

If you choose this option, the old belts will not be long enough anymore. You will have to replace them with longer ones.

Printing time for this project is quite extensive but you will not regret either the filament used or the time spent printing for one moment. Parts are easy to print without issues.

The end project is a professional looking antenna that looks and works well. Well worth your time spent.

I have seen many antenna designs here but none met my needs. I required a reasonably strong and light weight. The complete antenna weighs out at around 650 gram (~23 ounce) with good strength. My drawing skills are limited, hence mostly parametric parts readily available on Thingiverse were used.

This is an attempt to create an easily constructable 3D printed version of the excellent 2m/70cm 2+2/3 El antenna design by DK7ZB.
Web Page:
http://www.qsl.net/dk7zb/Duoband/duoband_2-70_2-3.htm

Should you require more bandwidth/better SWR on 70cm, you can build the antenna without the third 70cm element with a bit less gain. I suggest you read Martin, DK7ZBs page on the link above before deciding to build the antenna.

This antenna is seriously easy to build, sturdy and works as expected. It has a single feed point/driven element for both the 2m and 70cm bands. In my opinion it is worth the 3D printing time for an end product that just works and should provide many hours of pleasure afterwards.

Individual parametric parts are here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2252745
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2255051
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2252291

Tools Required:
2.5mm Drill (Drill 2 x 2.5mm holes one in each of the two driven elements for the feed point - holes can be drilled 5mm from the edge of the element)
M3 Tap (Tap the 2 x 2.5 drilled holes in the driven elements)
M5 Tap (Tap 5mm holes in the Element Holder)
M5 Die (Clean up thread on printed M5 Bolts)
Metric Allen Keys (Tighten M5 3D printed bolts (not too tight) and Stainless steel Bolts)
Soldering Iron (Solder your coax to eyelid connectors or connect directly to the driven element)

3D Printed Parts required:
1 x Yagi_El_Holder_16-55-WideWindow
4 x Yagi_El_Holder_16-55-NoWindow
10 x M5x10_Hex_Bolt
Optional 3D Pinted:
2 x Yagi end Cap 140-170-8

Other Parts Required:
15.88-16mm (1/4") x 520mm Aluminium tubing for the boom (Add 170 - 200 mm for a handle on the rear)
6mm Solid aluminium Rod (2 x 2.5m lengths were more than enough for me)
10 x M4 x 30mm Button head allen key bolts (To clamp the Boom to element brackets to the boom)
10 x M4 Nuts
2 x M3x6 Button head allen key bolts (Used to connect the coax to the driven element)

Build is quite simple. I followed the instructions as per the DK7ZB page.
The driven element of my antenna was assembled using LMR195 Coax. I drilled a 2.5mm hole 5mm from the edge of each driven element and tapped the holes to 3mm using the M3x5mm button head bolts in the tapped holes.

Should any of the info not be accurate or clear, please do not hesitate to contact me either here or by looking me up on QRZ. I will do my best at keeping this page as complete as possible and add all input received. My intention is to ensure a complete and easy to build antenna with full design instructions supplied. Please help me by contacting me should you feel that there are an additions or changes required in order to further clarify build instructions.

A simple PDF drawing of the complete Yagi has been added in the thing files for clarification purposes. Element lengths and placement positions on the boom are clearly indicated in order to assist with the build of the antenna.

73

Printer:

Velleman Vertex K8400

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

25% on Brackets. 100% on Bolts

title: SEEMECNC Rostock V2 Bed Tabs and Spacers

description.text: This is to help avoid heater warping the build surface from being clamped down directly on the edges and allow quicker bed removal. There is a larger lag and more of a temperature offset but initial printing post mod with slight stabilization time did not exhibit abs part delamination. I have added a extended tab. I did this to make a hot air pocket under the bed.

Flat head M3 x 20mm minimum needed length. A 25mm would be better. There are six of these on the V2 bed and the current screws can be used for the tabs. M3 nuts can be heated with a solder iron to set in the offsets or an actual heated insert can be used since it was designed for it. I personally used the nut due to no inserts were available.

This is a PlantPot for a Windowfarm. More Infos under windowfarms.org

-------------------------------------------------PLEASE READ-------------------------------------------------
This is a tool that uses the function of a regular Swiss army knife. It can hold (theoretically), as many keys as you want. You just may need to add longer screws, more spacers, and washers.

--Assembly--
(Please look at pictures while assembling)
1) Taking the top part (the one with the extra hole to put on a key chain) put two flat
screws in each hole.
2) Take a washer, placing on each of the screws.
3) Add a key spacer to the screw closest to the key chain hole, and a key on the other
screw. (This is so when the key opens, it doesn't run into the key chain.
4) Add washers on each screw
5) Repeat step 3, placing the key and spacer on the opposite sides.
6) Repeat steps until the desired amount of keys are on.
7) Place on the bottom piece and add the nuts, screwing hand tight (allowing room for
keys to move)

description.text:
Calibration tower for Makergeeks PETG filament, using their recommended temperature range.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915435

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=915435

You must modify the gcode before printing for the temperature changes.
The base on this print is 2mm, so the code to look for would be G1 Z12.000, G1 Z22.000, G1 Z32.000, etc. up to Z92.000.

For each, enter the temperature in the M109 command.
So for G1 Z12.00, we would set the temp to 240.
For G1 Z22.00, the temp would be 242. Etc.

For each of these, add the following snippet to the gcode:
G91 ; Set relative movement corordinates
G0 X2.0000 Y2.0000 Z2.0000 ; Rapid movement
M109 S240 ; Set temp and wait until it is reached.
G1 X-2.0000 Y-2.0000 Z-2.0000 ; Rapid movement back to print
G90 ; Set to absolute movement corordinates

AURA is the All Users Robotic Arm that you can create at home for 50$. All the information to make this robot, program it and more is in: http://aivrobotics.blogspot.com/ Check it out in: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_OyClmqwb4 I strongly encourage people to make it, to improve it, to adapt it and to use it as starting point in bigger projects. Specifications:
Degrees of freedom : 5
Weight: 520g
Maximum operative radius :30cm
Maximum gripper width : 6,84 cm
Total cost : 39,83 euros (around 50$) Accessories:
Holder Board: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:284847

Building instructions in: http://aivrobotics.blogspot.com/
In the files there is the project that explains every detail of the design and the constraction of AURA(Spanish Version), and the drafts to describe it and built it . The robotic arm is composed by 13 printable parts, 5 servos and a microcontroller. Every part needs to be printed just once except the "Phalange medial" that is doubled. The arm A, B and C are diveded into several pieces due to printing problems. You can print them at once or in their pieces and stuck them with cyanoacrylate.
The axes are made with the 3mm filament of the printing plastic, thanks to "jasonwelsh" that give the idea, Check his thing:(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:116571). Non printable parts:
Arduino Leonardo (microcontroller)
Servo Corona 939MG (servo m)
Servo HK15288A Analog BB/MG (servo beta)
Servo VS-11 Vigor Extra Large (servo alpha)
Servo Turnigy TGY-R5180MG (servos omega and gamma) For further information visit : http://aivrobotics.blogspot.com/

Gracias por vuestro interés en mi proyecto.
El brazo es perfectamente imprimible en PLA, simplemente yo no contaba con ese material en ese momento. Posiblemente tendrás que adaptar algunas propiedades de la impresión pero no hay ningún problema.
Este proyecto en su totalidad fue creado para inducir a la gente a la robótica, y no tiene ninguna legalidad de protección de datos, así que en cierto modo, ayudas a su objetivo usándolo en una presentación. Puedes utilizar toda la información que necesites.

comments.text: A doubt. In your paper "Diseño, desarrollo y construcción del brazo robótico" you tell that you used a 3D printer with a single extruder. Some parts have suspended elements that cannot be achieved with this type of printer. Other parts haven't reference planes. Did you cut some parts before printing?
comments.author: astoit

comments.text:
As you said, I have used a single extruder printer and I have divided few parts in different pieces, but most of them have been done at once using support material created by the slicer program (I normally use Skeinforge or Slic3r).
The pieces called Arm A, Arm B and Arm C are uploaded as a whole and in the sections I used for printing (Arm A1, Arm A2, etc), the rest of the pieces I have used support material from the same plastic and removed it after the impresion. Every piece is described on "AURA Drafts"
If for any reason you cannot use support material you can make your own division for printing or design some "columns" for the suspended elements.
comments.author: astoit

comments.text:
Thanks for the quick response. I solved a lot of doubts. There are two pieces on which I have some concerns.
COVER: I can cut it, but how? It is a very important part that supports the whole arm, so it is very stressed.
At the bottom there is the plug for the cross of the servo. I have to print it separately and then add it.
ARM A1: where do I cut?
PHALANGE PROXIMAL: it has a double fork at the ends, it is asymmetric. To make it, I have to cut it to length, but I weaken it or I then use a screw to join the two pieces
Is my reasoning correct?
comments.author: AIVrobotics

comments.text:
The phalange can be cut to length, there no that much forces on that one, for the others is different they both hold servos. You can build some columns and then remove them. For the design of the columns you can use simple internet cad like tinkercad (https://tinkercad.com/) or download the original files and modify them in solid edge (In my blog: aivrobotics.blogspot.com).
It is just to introduce a couple of thin cylinders in the middle so it can print, afterwards you remove them with the scissors or something like that.
But I still insist that most slicer programs are able of creating support material themselves so you just have to print i, Strongly suggest you to explore that possibility.

title: Easter Egg - Gift Wrap - Kinder Surprise

description.text:
I needed a suited gift wrap for a Scottish kilt pin.
Created this egg for it.
Next needed to make my printer pause and move head away in order to fill it with pin and goodies - read how below.

Printer:

Geeetech Rostock 301

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

-

Notes:

I mixed 15%white continuously with a varying 85%yellow up to 85%red. I let my suns determing when and what for that - that was fun!

Another strange/neat/... thing on the mixing hotend of the Geeetech Rostock 301 is that it doesn't mix that good, so the filament flowing out is like striped toothpaste. Every 120° viewpoint shows another dominant color :)

Give away - let people shake and guess.
If your gift is small enough, people can get to their surprise by pushing through the bottom (only 1mm thick - easy enough as push through)
Even breaking it halfway could work (shell = 2mm) depending on your on purpose or by sheer luck 3D printing settings/skills.
Glueing the gift wrap back together gives you a fine souvenir or decorative element.

Let your 3D printer pause is not that difficult - I was told.... you select "Change filament" on your display, your head moves away from your print and you do your thing. "Continue" after that.
The Geeetech Rostock 301 doesn't have such option. On my search for dwelling or pausing Gcodes, I only found more unsupported functions of this printer.

Still the solution is not too difficult: Edit Gcode in followin simple steps!

  1. determine the height where the egg opening is still big enough to fit in your gift and find out what layer that is "LAYER:xxx"
  2. find some G0 commands where you want to go in between with a pause - if possible choose this location on infill or support ";TYPE:FILL"-";TYPE:SUPPORT"
  3. insert a very slow move to a position close to home: G0 F100 X0 Y0 Z200 (change that for a cartesian printer!)
  4. copy the next G0 code (without F parameter if there is any) and add an additional Z height parameter matching the current layer height (so will still move slow)

I recommend a test on a low layer to get the hang of it and test without too much filament loss in case you mess up something.
Myself I have plenty of G0s using Cura2.4 with "Coasting" on (0.5mm³!!)

For Geeetech Rostock 301: since the hotend oozes like crazy: clean up the leaving point as fast as possible such that the returning head lateron doesn't suffer from a blob of filament. (sharp knife! don't rip your print loose from the bed!)
Also equally important: push some additional filament when returning such that the hotend is'nt empty for the next like 5cm - still: don't worry too much about this when you select a pause location before infill or support.

Example -ORIGINAL-
G0 F3000 X-13.858 Y6.619
;TIME_ELAPSED:247.920506
;LAYER:3
G0 X-13.815 Y6.709 Z0.87
G0 X-13.038 Y6.236
G0 X-13.465 Y5.226
;TYPE:SUPPORT

Example -MODIFIED-
G0 F3000 X-13.858 Y6.619
;TIME_ELAPSED:247.920506
;LAYER:3
G0 X-13.815 Y6.709 Z0.87
G0 X-13.038 Y6.236
;MB3Y GEEETECH ROSTOCK 301 PAUSE
G0 F100 X0 Y0 Z200
G0 X-13.465 Y5.226 Z0.87
;MAYBE PUSH SOME FILAMENT BY HAND NOW
;MB3Y GEEETECH ROSTOCK 301 PAUSE
G0 X-13.465 Y5.226
;TYPE:SUPPORT

author: Deerslayer_1

print_settings.Notes:: Print with ABS.

title: Adding MK3 heatbed to Vertex K8400

description.text:
Adding heatbed to VERTEX K8400 is not as difficult as one may think. Here is the list of parts that I used:

  • MK3 heatbead
  • Velleman's 24VDC 150W power supply
  • 3D Printer Heated Bed Power Module
  • NTC 3950 100K Thermistor with Wiring
  • Heat resistant silicon
  • Sheet of 5mm cork
  • Several M3 screws
  • Several 3d printed parts

I bought the parts from reprapchampion.com They have good prices and ship the same business day. I also purchased 2 pieces of Borosilicate Glass 219x219mm, but so far I was not able to find a good way to mount them on top of MK3, which is 220x220mm. That's why at the moment I'm using the original 4mm glass that came with K8400. Binder clips could be an option, but they take space and complicate glass installation and removal. Ideal solution would be to buy a bigger 3mm Borosilicate glass and cut it to the dimensions of the original glass (240mm x 215mm).

Attached Files

I am attaching several STL files, but the only one you really need is called corner.stl. Four corner things keep the original glass in place.

  • Corner.stl was designed to fit the "sandwich" of the original aluminum bed plate covered by 5mm cork sheet with MK3 heatbed on top of it.
  • side.stl thing stops the glass from side movement. It is optional, as the corner things do the same.
  • bottom_under.stl, top_center.stl, heatbed_connectors.stl, heatbed_connectors_cover.stl and bottom-center.stl files are for those who installed my wire covers posted here. Old wire covers need to be replaced to accommodate additional wires.
  • center_mount_bottom.stl, center_mount_TOP.stl and center_mount.stl things are mounted to the center of printer’s bottom panel. center_mount.stl houses Heated Bed Power Module and Raspberry Pi’s power supply board; I extracted it from Pi’s standard power supply. center_mount_TOP.stl is just a decorative piece that you can glue on top of center_mount.stl to cover the fan opening in bottom panel. center_mount_bottom.stl is the bottom cover for center_mount.stl. It also holds Raspberry Pi’s power supply board in place.
  • power_supply_safety.stl thing covers the connectors of 24VDC power supply, to protect user from accidentally touching them.
Wiring

You will need to add 5 sets of wires:
1) Connect AC power cord or power switch to newly added power supply (2 wires + ground wire)
2) Connect power supply to Printer Heated Bed Power Module (2 wires)
3) Connect Printer Heated Bed Power Module to MK3 bed (2 wires)
4) Connect thermistor attached to the heatbed to the mainboard (2 wires)
5) Connect mainboard to Printer Heated Bed Power Module (2 wires)
If you have Raspberry Pi mounted to the printer and want to move its power supply into center_mount.stl thing, you will need 2 additional sets of wires:
6) From AC power cord or power switch to Pi power supply card (2 wires) and
7) from Pi power supply card to Raspberry (2 wires)

How to run the wires is up to you. It will depend on where you install 24VDC power supply and power module, and if you want heatbed to be removable. I opted for the later and installed additional connectors for the wires going towards MK3. I used 2 Position Terminal Strip as 24VDC connector and 2 Pin 0.1" Polarized Locking Header for thermistor wires. They both are housed in center_mount.stl thing. Thermistor connector is soldered to a little piece of prototype board that slides into center_mount.stl thing from the back.

Assembly instructions

Start with gluing the thermistor into the center hole of MK3 with heat resistant silicon. It will take about 24 hours to completely dry.

Print all the things posted here, but do not change the position of Z-stop sensor. Drill the hole in aluminum bed plate as shown in the image from that post.

Drill 6 additional holes in the bed plate. 4 holes with 3.2mm diameter should be aligned with the mounting screw holes of MK3 (see image). Put MK3 on top of the bed plate, align it to be in the very center and mark 4 points to drill. 2 other holes with M3 thread inside are needed for front-left and rear-right glass holders. Bed plate already has similar holes in 2 other corners (see image).

Print 4 copies of corner.stl thing. ABS would be the preferred option. Use 0.2mm resolution.

Once all parts are available, start from locating the place where you mount 24VDC power supply. If you printed and intend to use cente_mount thing, install it temporarily and then find the place where you can fit 24VDC power supply. The way I mounted mine is shown on attached images. You will need to drill 4 holes in the bottom panel of the printer for M3 mounting screws. Use 5mm high spacers to keep distance between the power supply and printer’s bottom panel. Mounting screws should be M3 x 12mm.

Use four M3 x 6mm screws to mount heatbed power module to center_mount.stl thing. Raspberry Pi power supply board simply slides in and does not require screws.

Place MK3 on top of cork sheet and cut the cork along MK3 edges with sharp knife. Cut the “channel” in the cork along the thermostat wires. Cut the cork around MK3 soldering pads and mounting holes.

Put all things together as shown on the images. While installing wiring make sure to properly connect the positive and negative wires, where applicable. Use pads #2 and #3 to feed MK3 with 24VDC. If you purchased 12VDC power supply, connect pad #2 to pad #3 and feed 12V between these 2 pads and pad #1.

No firmware changes are required. Mainboard detects the presence of heatbed as soon as you connect heatbed thermistor to it.

Update 21-June-2017
Uploaded new revision of heatbed_connectors thing. Relocated thermostat connector and added cover.

Printer:

VERTEX K8400 with E3D print-heads

Print with ABS.

comments.text: You could also connect 24V to pads #1 and #2&3 (solder 2 und 3 together). That lowers the heatbed resistance and it draws up to 16A (380W). 100°C in less than 5min.
comments.author: LuckyLuzz

comments.text: Mine heats up in 8 min. Considering that heating up E3D nozzle to 240°C takes 3.5 minutes and you can do this is parallel with heating up the bed, the gain is only 4.5 minutes that is nothing comparing to average thing printing time. However, by doubling the voltage you reduce the lifetime of the bed and in addition you need more powerful (i.e. bigger) power supply.

Use clamp mod 1 for the greatest flexibility in number of syringes you can use.

title: Mini Monster Willy with rotating wheels
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
OK this is my first ever remix of anything so it was a learning experience, I could have done some further improvements but in the end I'm happy enough with the end-result.

This is a mash up of many other projects the willy jeep and suspension frame is from "Mini Monster Willy" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1958890

I split the frame from the jeep so I could print it separately and in different colour. After I printed my fist jeep I noticed the Steering wheel and shifters broke quite easily. I redesigned these to be thicker and stronger.
Next I borrowed the wheels from "Remix Mini Monster Truck w/ Rotating Wheels" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1946877
Here I used the Emmett's Gear Bearing wheels and tires
I modified the frame to accept the wheels and added a small cube to help the frame and Jeep body align correctly, it needs to be glued as I didn't figure out a better way to get them to attach without glue.

Supports are needed for the frame and the steering wheel on the jeep the original design had it built-in but i decided to to add it manually through my slicer instead (great for me maybe not for others)

I probably missed some info or forgot something so I'll update and fix when I can

print_settings.Notes:: The parts have been designed with very little tolerance - you might find that some filing will be required if your printer has any slop - especially with the 608 bearing holes.

description.text:
This is a do-it-yourself rope winder using ancient techniques!

UPDATE 2017/0/19: The Hook.stl and Hook_Mechanism.stl files have been changed due to a slight cough mistake cough. My apologies if you've already printed them - the collar around the hook must go otherwise it interferes with the bearing. File it off or reprint the new hook.
My bad!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 for gears, 0.25 for the rest

Infill:

25%

Notes:

The parts have been designed with very little tolerance - you might find that some filing will be required if your printer has any slop - especially with the 608 bearing holes.

Step 1: Parts

You'll need the following parts printed:
1x Annulus
1x Front
3x Hook mechanism
1x Knob
1x Shuttle

You'll also need the following hardware items:
5x 608Z or 608ZZ bearing (A standard 22mm OD, 8mm ID, 7mm high) http://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/ball-bearings/4089883
2x M8 machine bolt (with hex head for a size 13 metric spanner)
2x M8 nut (size 13 spanner) - I used 1x Nyloc nut but I don't believe it's necessary.
2x M8 washers

Step 2: Assembly of bearings

Insert the bearings into the 5 holes as appropriate (ensure you're inserting from the wider side!)
If the bearings are a little tough to insert (possibly due to printer tolerances etc.), then a method would be to "Pull" them through into the holes by using another bearing on the side you're pulling towards, then tightening a nut & bolt so that the action of tightening them pulls the bearing into place. Alternatively a wooden block and light taps with a hammer.

Step 3: Assembly of hook and gears

Insert the stem of the hooks through the bearings in the 3 Front part holes and into a Gear part. Ensure that the gear part is orientated so that lip of the gear points towards the hook and the hook stem clicks into place firmly inside the gear. Push an anchor wedge piece into the gap that is now at the back of the gear. This wedge should jam the gear on to the end of the hook to prevent it from pulling out.

Step 4: Assembly of handle

Drop an M8 nut into the hollow of the knob so that it aligns with the hole on the underneath.
Insert an M8 bolt into the Annulus bearing on the outer edge so that the bolt enters from the gear side and passes out of the flat side. Screw this into the knob handle so that the bolt enters the embedded nut. Tighten up so that the handle moves freely.

Step 5: Joining together

Insert an M8 bolt from the center of the smooth side of the Annulus part so that the head fits into the hex shaped hole designed for it. Place 2 washers on the side of the bolt that exits on the gear side (will be between the front and back).
The gears which are attached to the front part should mesh within the outer annulus gear ring. Attempt to orientate all the hooks in the upwards direction when the handle is at the bottom - this just makes it easier to use later. Put the front (with gears) and the annulus part together and secure with M8 nut on the central M8 bolt.

Step 6: Test

If you have correctly printed the parts and put them together, you should be able to freely move the handle and the annulus should spin causing the hooks to spin even faster. If you want you can now g-clamp this on to a bench or bolt it down using the anchor holes in order to make it sturdy and easy to use. (It is still possible to use it without anchoring though).

Step 7: Try it out!

The trick of winding ropes is to do the following:
Cut at least 3 pieces of string of the same length - the final rope will normally be about a third of the length of the string strands.
Pass each piece of string around a hook so that the ends all meet together in line with the center front of the rope winder.
Tie a thumb knot on the end of the strings to control them.
Insert the shuttle so that each of the 3 slots contain the string for the associated hook and keep them from getting tangled and take the shuttle to the knot at the end.
This part will need 2 people. One person is in charge of the shuttle and the end of the rope and the other is in charge of the rope winder.
The rope winder is cranked while the shuttle is held steady to keep the strings straight.
The strings twist on themselves and build up tension.
As the tension reach the shuttle it will cause the knot to start to twist.
At this point the shuttle operator helps the knot to twist in the direction it is trying to turn and the shuttle is moved slightly forward towards the winder keeping the strings straight.
Rope should form on the other side of the shuttle!
When the shuttle reaches the winder it can be removed and the string looped over the hooks is removed and another thumb knot tied.

This is fairly tricky to get right but so rewarding! Try pair pieces of colored wool with the strings to get a cool effect or bright ropes for whatever projects you want!

A video to cover some concepts (Not my video!) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=toyOKOi0DsM and here is a video of it in action! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jD_0a4PvXs

author: YlooC

title: Anet A8 - sturdy elongated filament guide

description.text:
I keep my the filament rolls above the printer, and I've tried a couple of other filament guides for the Anet A8 before designing this. However, filament was always binding or catching somewhere, especially for larger prints. So I decided to make something sturdy that will attach well to the frame and give me an elongated smooth opening. See the pictures---my design attaches in 3 places to the frame: both sides of the display section, and also all the way on the frame right above the display. Still, it's on top of the display, thus not blocking the screen and buttons, and there's space for the cables as well. I intentionally did not leave an opening for loading the filament, because not only I find this feature useless, but also it would be counter-productive for having smooth opening that filament won't catch on.

I printed this in 0.2mm layer height, 15% infill. Make sure you rotate this diagonally in your slicer and print it with the legs sticking up (hence no supports needed). Print at 100%, because initially when you load it in Cura (or whatever you're using), it might scale it down to fit depending on your default settings. Rotated diagonally, it fits perfectly on the A8 bed with lots of space to spare.

description.text:
For our Make It 101 class, we needed to make a project where we used everyday readily available materials to make a connector set. I used toilet and napkin paper tubes as my "connectors." I designed two different parts and used them to make a pyramid type of thing. In the instructions, I mention another part: a smaller connector tube. That part can be replaced by the regular tube connector. Both the parts can be printed with ABS or PLA. For both of these parts, I did not use support, so the parts were sightly deformed, but the damage was not that bad, so I suggest that you can print them both without support. Make sure for the tube, you change the orientation so that the tube lies flat on the 3D printer base. Same for the 6 hole connector.
If we let children play with this, they can create other things that use their creativity. This can be used to learn shapes and build anything that one can think of. Because toilet paper can be bent and turned into different things, it is a really useful connector. Hope you guys enjoy this project and share what you built with this project.

How I created this

I measured the diameters of the toilet paper tubes, and made the size of my hole slightly smaller, so that the tubes would be snug inside the tubes. There is usually one universal size for the toilet paper tube, but if not you can always change the size of the hole depending on your paper tube. Use a CAD program like Onshape to change the size. = Each of the pieces took some time to print. Printing two of the tube design and 4 of the six hole connector took like 8 hours to print. I suggest that if you are going to print overnight, use PLA, because it will have less deformity because the plastic is not as how so it will cool and harden faster.

description.text: For our school project we had to make a modular construction kit, sort of like Lego blocks but instead of bricks we made connectors to combine together common household items. I decided to use straws and I 3-D printed the connectors to hold them together. Parents, I guarantee your children will LOVE this. In a student testing for my project it got rated an average of 4.5/5. Even if your not a child, I promise that you'll still love the complex models and flexibility of my design. You may have to adjust the measurements based on your straw though.

We were tasked to create a construction kit for an everyday thing. I chose rounded number 2 pencils. I designed and created 5 different connectors with OnShape and 3D printers. I cut the pencils at different lengths in order to create more structures. I chose to create a car because I always loved things that could role and it was one of the easier ideas I had considering the time frame. The designing process was fun but challenging. I found it really hard to keep up with my timeline because the I had issues with the 3D printers. Once I finally was able to print out the parts I had to make adjustments to it because most of the time it did not fit. Overall, it was a great experience for me to be able to think of something to build and actually create it. I was able to learn how to use a 3D printer for the first time and can use it decently most of the time. In the future I would recommend more time to print because I learned that 3D printers aren't perfect. All in all, this project was really fun and I highly recommend it.

I had to design a model with an everyday object. I chose rounded number 2 pencils because as a kid I had all kinds of pencils ranging from regular pencils to colored pencils. I measured the width of the pencils with a caliper. I found out that you have to make some adjustments when you 3D print because it may come out smaller. My pieces took about 5 to 15 min. If you print out multiple pieces at a time it may take longer. I used a saw to cut different lengths of the pencils to be able to create more things.

description.text:
MoleBox system - 3D printed boxes compatible with BITBEAM construction kit (therefore even with LEGO Technics/Mindstorms). The main purpose of MoleBox is covering a particular sensor or the entire module and simultaneously allowing variable fixing sensors/modules. MoleBoxes are suitable for measurements with Arduino (MoleGraph, school measuring system based on Arduino) or even as part of a robotic construction (m-BITBEAM).

  • Sample measuring code and MoleGraph template (ZIP)
  • HX711 libraries (bodge HX711)
  • HX711 data sheet (PDF)
  • HX711 module (Aliexpress)

More info on e-Mole MoleBox page (czech only).

Detailed building instructions in the journal e-Mole no. 9 (czech, lot of photos).

author: Jrosel

description.text:
Just me, PTC Creo, and a couple of hours to spare.
I have made it without any patterns so that the elements are all easily seen.
It is not in any way as detailed as I would like it to be, but with my crappy computer, I crash Creo every time I open it. :(
Please download and edit! I mean for this as a template for people to use and modify. Please, show it to me before you publish again (because I am selfish and like to see what other people are doing :P)
I would not recommend printing this, I have not myself and will not, but if you want, go ahead.
I would love to see!
If you want it in a different format, please leave a comment and I will get back to you ASAP!

Thanks!

Nanek

title: Dual Radial Cooling Fan Duct/Mount for Tevo Tarantula Dual Extruder (Chimera)

description.text:
This part was remixed from code10's C10 Duo for the single extruder tarantula, and uses the same ducts on the ends of the fans. Be sure to print those from the original post!

I used two genuine Delta BGB0412HHA 40x40x10mm radial blower fans, which move a lot of air.

https://www.arrow.com/en/products/bfb0412hha-a/delta-electronics

As of right now this part remains untested, but I will update the Thingiverse entry once I receive my tarantula and begin printing with these fans.

title: Monoprice Maker Select v2 locking Filament Guide

description.text:
Remix of the bigger Monoprice Maker Select v2 filament guide. This one locks onto the frame so it doesn't move around as easily.

Also, the flat part under the rotating guide is just a support I added because Cura kept messing mine up when I tried to print with the default supports. I can upload a version without it if anybody wants that. And you do still have to print with supports, but the supports build up from that piece to the bottom of the rotating guide.

comments.text: Not really sure what the deal is, but for some reason the print doesn't fit on the frame very well. I am thinking that if were extended even 1-2mm it would make all the difference. I posted my Made if you want to see.  Also, the raft for the sphere ended up having pretty stringy filament between it and the sphere.  May be settings or cooling issues.  Overall I like it though!
comments.author: artauermaker

comments.text: Thank you. Sorry, I designed this based off of a similar filament guide about 5 months ago. I think I had to sand down the locking overhang a little bit, but it did fit on my frame once it pushed past that part. I'll see if I can modify it to have less of an overhang stopping it from locking onto the frame and reupload
comments.author: artauermaker

comments.text: Awesome, thanks!
